nodes.title: Add more heuristics to detect SPARQL endpoints

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :heavy_plus_sign: Feature request ____ #### Description: Currently, Comunica detects if a source is a SPARQL endpoint by looking for a valid SPARQL service description, or if the URL ends with `/sparql` or `/sparql/`. We could however add some additional heuristics to do this check. For example, we could look at the HTTP response headers, to see if a specific SPARQL engine was used. If this engine matches some regex, we could guess it's a valid SPARQL endpoint. Concretely, what we need is a new metadata extract actor for the HTTP `Server` header, which we could for example name `actor-rdf-metadata-extract-server-software`. (but other endpoints _may_ require detection from other headers as well, so more actors may be needed) Next, we can modify `actor-query-source-identify-hypermedia-sparql`, to inspect this extracted server header in the metadata object, and match it against a list of strings or regular expressions. This list should be defined in the actor with a sane default list of values. We should have at least support for the following endpoint types (but more is better): - Virtuoso (public example at https://dbpedia.org/sparql) (e.g. `Server: Virtuoso/08.03.3332 (Linux) x86_64-generic-linux-glibc212 VDB`) - Blazegraph - Amazon Neptune - RDF4J - Jena Fuseki (http://agrovoc.uniroma2.it/sparql) - GraphDB (https://api.parliament.uk/sparql) - Stardog - QLever So some work will have to be invested in finding and analyzing existing endpoints. Ideally, we should have a report as outcome of this issue summarizing which endpoint types require which detection heuristics, together with a list of public endpoint URLs we can test with. This list of public endpoint URLs should also be included in our [system tests](https://github.com/comunica/comunica/blob/master/engines/query-sparql/test/QuerySparql-test.ts). ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨1088 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Issue type:

  • ‚ûï Feature request

Description:

Currently, Comunica detects if a source is a SPARQL endpoint by looking for a valid SPARQL service description, or if the URL ends with /sparql or /sparql/.

We could however add some additional heuristics to do this check.
For example, we could look at the HTTP response headers, to see if a specific SPARQL engine was used.
If this engine matches some regex, we could guess it's a valid SPARQL endpoint.

Concretely, what we need is a new metadata extract actor for the HTTP Server header, which we could for example name actor-rdf-metadata-extract-server-software. (but other endpoints may require detection from other headers as well, so more actors may be needed)

Next, we can modify actor-query-source-identify-hypermedia-sparql, to inspect this extracted server header in the metadata object, and match it against a list of strings or regular expressions.
This list should be defined in the actor with a sane default list of values.

We should have at least support for the following endpoint types (but more is better):

  • Virtuoso (public example at https://dbpedia.org/sparql) (e.g. Server: Virtuoso/08.03.3332 (Linux) x86_64-generic-linux-glibc212 VDB)
  • Blazegraph
  • Amazon Neptune
  • RDF4J
  • Jena Fuseki (http://agrovoc.uniroma2.it/sparql)
  • GraphDB (https://api.parliament.uk/sparql)
  • Stardog
  • QLever

So some work will have to be invested in finding and analyzing existing endpoints.
Ideally, we should have a report as outcome of this issue summarizing which endpoint types require which detection heuristics, together with a list of public endpoint URLs we can test with.
This list of public endpoint URLs should also be included in our system tests.

Bounty

A bounty has been placed on this issue by:
‚Ç¨1088

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: DELETE/INSERT is deleting the quad but not updating the same value in the data store.

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :bug: Bug ____ #### Description: In case of DELETE/INSERT query, if I am updating a quad with the same value as in datastore, apparently the quad is being deleted but it should update the quad to the same value resulting in no change. Following the third example at https://comunica.dev/docs/query/getting_started/update_app/ ``` console.log("initial size = ", store.size); // prints 6 // for president25, renaming to the same name. await myEngine.queryVoid( ` PREFIX foaf: DELETE { foaf:givenName ?name } INSERT { foaf:givenName ?name } WHERE { foaf:givenName ?name }`, { sources: [store], } ); console.log("updated size = ", store.size); // prints 5 ``` or if I try putting the same name in the query in INSERT ``` console.log("initial size = ", store.size); // prints 6 // for president25, renaming to the same name. await myEngine.queryVoid( ` PREFIX foaf: DELETE { foaf:givenName ?name } INSERT { foaf:givenName 'Bill'} WHERE { foaf:givenName ?name }`, { sources: [store], } ); console.log("updated size = ", store.size); // prints 5 ``` in both above cases, 1 quad is removed which is obvious due to the DELETE, but a new quad is not being inserted. Why is it so? GraphDB behaves differently for the same query, it deletes the quad but inserts in back again for the same value. ____ #### Environment: `node v18.6.0` `"@comunica/query-sparql": "^2.10.2"` `"n3": "^1.17.2"` #### Crash log: ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨272 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Issue type:

  • üêõ Bug

Description:

In case of DELETE/INSERT query, if I am updating a quad with the same value as in datastore, apparently the quad is being deleted but it should update the quad to the same value resulting in no change.

Following the third example at https://comunica.dev/docs/query/getting_started/update_app/

  console.log("initial size = ", store.size); // prints 6

  // for president25, renaming to the same name.
  await myEngine.queryVoid(
    `
    PREFIX foaf:  <http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/>
    DELETE { <http://example/president25> foaf:givenName ?name }
    INSERT { <http://example/president25> foaf:givenName ?name }
    WHERE
    {
      <http://example/president25> foaf:givenName ?name
    }`,
    {
      sources: [store],
    }
  );
  console.log("updated size = ", store.size); // prints 5

or if I try putting the same name in the query in INSERT

  console.log("initial size = ", store.size); // prints 6

  // for president25, renaming to the same name.
  await myEngine.queryVoid(
    `
    PREFIX foaf:  <http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/>
    DELETE { <http://example/president25> foaf:givenName ?name }
    INSERT { <http://example/president25> foaf:givenName 'Bill'}
    WHERE
    {
      <http://example/president25> foaf:givenName ?name
    }`,
    {
      sources: [store],
    }
  );
  console.log("updated size = ", store.size); // prints 5

in both above cases, 1 quad is removed which is obvious due to the DELETE, but a new quad is not being inserted.
Why is it so?

GraphDB behaves differently for the same query, it deletes the quad but inserts in back again for the same value.

Environment:

node v18.6.0
"@comunica/query-sparql": "^2.10.2"
"n3": "^1.17.2"

Crash log:

Bounty

A bounty has been placed on this issue by:
‚Ç¨272

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: Duplicate bindings on construct query

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :heavy_plus_sign: Feature request ____ #### Description: I get unexpected results with `comunica-sparql https://lab.coret.org/rdf/c1.jsonld -q 'CONSTRUCT WHERE { ?p ?o ; ?d . ?d ?e ?f }'`. The output contains a lot of duplicate triples (like some kind of Cartesian product): ``` , . "Distributie 1a". , . "Distributie 1a". "Keyword 1"; . "Distributie 1a". "Keyword 2"; . "Distributie 1a". a ; . "Distributie 1a". , . "Distributie 1b". , . "Distributie 1b". "Keyword 1"; . "Distributie 1b". "Keyword 2"; . "Distributie 1b". a ; . "Distributie 1b". ``` The [source graph](https://lab.coret.org/rdf/c1.jsonld) in Turtle being: ``` @prefix rdf: . @prefix schema: . a schema:Dataset ; schema:distribution , ; schema:keywords "Keyword 1", "Keyword 2" . schema:description "Distributie 1a" . schema:description "Distributie 1b" . ``` The expected result (as given by Apache Jena and GraphDB): ``` a ; , ; "Keyword 1" , "Keyword 2" . "Distributie 1b" . "Distributie 1a" . ``` The issue is not with the comunica-sparql CLI tool, but with the comunica core. This issue is a slimmed down version of the issue as we encounter with the NDE Dataset Register - https://github.com/netwerk-digitaal-erfgoed/dataset-register/issues/831 - where we use Comunica a lot. In this particular case the number of bindings explodes above our set maximum of 50000. ____ #### Environment: | software | version | ------------------- | ------- | Comunica Init Actor | 1.22.2 | node | v16.14.2 | npm | 9.7.1 | yarn | 1.22.19 | Operating System | linux (Linux 6.1.0-13-amd64) ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨272 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: query interface adds prefix declarations before executing query

repository.name: jQuery-Widget.js
repository.description: üñº A jQuery widget to query heterogeneous interfaces using Comunica SPARQL

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :bug: Bug ____ #### Description: The query interface at https://query.linkeddatafragments.org seems to add prefix declarations before executing a query, even if these conflict with prefix declarations that are typed into the input. If I configure a datasource `https://query.wikidata.org/sparql` and enter this query: ```sparql PREFIX owl: PREFIX rdf: PREFIX rdfs: SELECT ?s ?o WHERE { ?s rdf:type ?o . } LIMIT 10 ``` I get an error from the SPARQL endpoint: `java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: org.openrdf.query.MalformedQueryException: Multiple prefix declarations for prefix 'owl'` I don't see a way in the UI to configure which prefix declarations are added, or not. ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨136 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Issue type:

  • üêõ Bug

Description:

The query interface at https://query.linkeddatafragments.org seems to add prefix declarations before executing a query, even if these conflict with prefix declarations that are typed into the input. If I configure a datasource https://query.wikidata.org/sparql and enter this query:

PREFIX owl: <http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#>
PREFIX rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
PREFIX rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#>
SELECT ?s ?o
WHERE {
  ?s rdf:type ?o .
}
LIMIT 10

I get an error from the SPARQL endpoint: java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: org.openrdf.query.MalformedQueryException: Multiple prefix declarations for prefix 'owl'

I don't see a way in the UI to configure which prefix declarations are added, or not.

Bounty

A bounty has been placed on this issue by:
‚Ç¨136

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: FILTER on langString literals does not work with N3 as source

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.bodyHTML:
// add a quad with a language string
const store = new N3.Store();
store.addQuad(namedNode('http://ex.com/s'), namedNode('http://ex.com/p'), literal('abc', 'en'));

// query it using SPARQL with a FILTER
const eng = new comunica.QueryEngine();
const bindings = await eng.queryBindings('SELECT ?o WHERE { ?s ?p ?o. FILTER(?o = "abc"@en) }', { sources: [ store ] });

Any FILTER on ?o in the example fails (with or without language string, = or !=). That is, as soon as a FILTER on the langString literal is present in the query, it won't return any results anymore. No crash or log warnings, just an empty result set.

Observed on Comunica v2.6.0 in combination with N3 v1.16.3.

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :bug: Bug ____ #### Description: The following code test throws "EXISTS found, but no existence hook provided" but should pass Note that these queries worked in @comunica/actor-init-sparql-rdfjs Also presumably similar issue to https://github.com/comunica/comunica/issues/650 ``` import 'mocha' import n3 from 'n3' import { QueryEngine } from '@comunica/query-sparql-rdfjs' import chai from 'chai' const sparql = new QueryEngine() describe('comunica sparql', () => { it('Does not support EXISTS sparql keyword', async () => { const store = new n3.Store() const subject = n3.DataFactory.namedNode('http://subject') const predicate = n3.DataFactory.namedNode('http://predicate') const object = n3.DataFactory.namedNode('http://object') const blank = n3.DataFactory.blankNode() const spo = n3.DataFactory.quad(subject, predicate, object) const bpo = n3.DataFactory.quad(blank, predicate, object) store.addQuads([spo, bpo]) const quadStream = await sparql.queryQuads(` CONSTRUCT { ?s ?p ?o. } WHERE { ?s ?p ?o. OPTIONAL { FILTER EXISTS { ?s2 ?p ?o. FILTER (?s != ?s2) } } } `, { sources: [store] }) const result_quads = await quadStream.toArray() chai.expect(result_quads).to.deep.equal([{ termType: 'Quad', value: '', graph: { termType: 'DefaultGraph', value: '', }, subject: { id: 'http://subject', }, predicate: { id: 'http://predicate', }, object: { id: 'http://object', }, }, { termType: 'Quad', value: '', graph: { termType: 'DefaultGraph', value: '', }, subject: { termType: 'BlankNode', value: 'bc_0_n3-01', }, predicate: { id: 'http://predicate', }, object: { id: 'http://object', }, }]) }) }) ``` ____ #### Environment: `node ./packages/actor-init-query/bin/query.js -v`--> not part of "@comunica/query-sparql-rdfjs": "^2.3.0", #### Crash log: NA ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨136 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Issue type:

  • üêõ Bug

Description:

The following code test throws "EXISTS found, but no existence hook provided" but should pass
Note that these queries worked in @comunica/actor-init-sparql-rdfjs
Also presumably similar issue to #650

import 'mocha'
import n3 from 'n3'
import { QueryEngine } from '@comunica/query-sparql-rdfjs'
import chai from 'chai'

const sparql = new QueryEngine()

describe('comunica sparql', () => {
  it('Does not support EXISTS sparql keyword', async () => {
    const store = new n3.Store()
    const subject = n3.DataFactory.namedNode('http://subject')
    const predicate = n3.DataFactory.namedNode('http://predicate')
    const object = n3.DataFactory.namedNode('http://object')
    const blank = n3.DataFactory.blankNode()
    const spo = n3.DataFactory.quad(subject, predicate, object)
    const bpo = n3.DataFactory.quad(blank, predicate, object)
    store.addQuads([spo, bpo])
    const quadStream = await sparql.queryQuads(`
      CONSTRUCT {
        ?s ?p ?o.
      }
      WHERE { 
        ?s ?p ?o.
        OPTIONAL {
          FILTER EXISTS {
            ?s2 ?p ?o.
            FILTER (?s != ?s2)
          }
        }
      }
      `,
      { sources: [store] })
    const result_quads = await quadStream.toArray()
    chai.expect(result_quads).to.deep.equal([{
      termType: 'Quad',
      value: '',
      graph: {
        termType: 'DefaultGraph',
        value: '',
      },
      subject: {
        id: 'http://subject',
      },
      predicate: {
        id: 'http://predicate',
      },
      object: {
        id: 'http://object',
      },
    }, {
      termType: 'Quad',
      value: '',
      graph: {
        termType: 'DefaultGraph',
        value: '',
      },
      subject: {
        termType: 'BlankNode',
        value: 'bc_0_n3-01',
      },
      predicate: {
        id: 'http://predicate',
      },
      object: {
        id: 'http://object',
      },
    }])
  })
})

Environment:

node ./packages/actor-init-query/bin/query.js -v--> not part of "@comunica/query-sparql-rdfjs": "^2.3.0",

Crash log:

NA

‚Ç¨136

nodes.title: INSERT DATA query on solid pod crashes in browser - again

repository.name: comunica-feature-solid
repository.description: üì¨ Comunica packages for query execution over Solid data pods

nodes.body: _This issue has been modified by @rubensworks to describe the intended solution_ **Problem:** The external [`solid-client-authn-js`](https://github.com/inrupt/solid-client-authn-js) has a [bug](https://github.com/inrupt/solid-client-authn-js/issues/2178) that makes it pass incorrect content types on PUT requests. This only occurs in browsers, not in Node.js. **Possible solution:** Since the bug only seems to occur when using headers using a `Headers` object, and not when passing headers as a plain record, we may be able to work around it by just converting our `Headers` object to a record. **Implementation suggestions:** The same workaround as [here](https://github.com/comunica/comunica/blob/master/packages/actor-http-fetch/lib/ActorHttpFetch.ts#L56-L59) could be applied [here](https://github.com/comunica/comunica/blob/master/packages/actor-http-fetch/lib/FetchInitPreprocessor-browser.ts). ----- Original issue: #### Issue type: - :bug: Bug ____ #### Description: I'm trying to do an insert query using `@comunica/query-sparql-solid` in a next.js + typescript app. I recently ran into another problem reported here (https://github.com/comunica/comunica-feature-solid/issues/22) with a very similar setup. I since switched from the deprecated `@comunica/actor-init-sparql-solid` to `@comunica/query-sparql-solid`. Therefore, the same pre-condition applies: the same query works when executed via command line. This is what I'm trying to do in my TypeScript code: ``` const insertQuery = ` INSERT DATA { <${ getDefaultSession().info.webId?.split("#")[0] }#Seppli> 'Seppli'. } `; console.log(insertQuery); await engine.queryVoid(insertQuery, { sources: [getDefaultSession().info.webId!], "@comunica/actor-http-inrupt-solid-client-authn:session": getDefaultSession(), }); ``` Full code available [here](https://github.com/remodietlicher/comunica-solid-react-test). But it fails with this error: [Unsupported patch content type: text/plain](https://pastebin.com/TMexGNpM). ____ #### Environment: comunica-solid-react-test (main)$ ./node_modules/.bin/comunica-sparql-solid -v | software | version | ---------------- | ------- | Comunica Engine | 2.0.6 | node | v16.14.0 | npm | 8.3.1 | yarn | 1.22.17 | Operating System | linux (Linux 5.13.0-37-generic) #### Crash log: https://pastebin.com/TMexGNpM ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨272 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
This issue has been modified by @rubensworks to describe the intended solution

Problem:

The external solid-client-authn-js has a bug that makes it pass incorrect content types on PUT requests.

This only occurs in browsers, not in Node.js.

Possible solution:

Since the bug only seems to occur when using headers using a Headers object, and not when passing headers as a plain record, we may be able to work around it by just converting our Headers object to a record.

Implementation suggestions:

The same workaround as here could be applied here.

Original issue:

Issue type:

  • üêõ Bug

Description:

I'm trying to do an insert query using @comunica/query-sparql-solid in a next.js + typescript app. I recently ran into another problem reported here (#22) with a very similar setup. I since switched from the deprecated @comunica/actor-init-sparql-solid to @comunica/query-sparql-solid. Therefore, the same pre-condition applies: the same query works when executed via command line. This is what I'm trying to do in my TypeScript code:

    const insertQuery = `
      INSERT DATA {
        <${
          getDefaultSession().info.webId?.split("#")[0]
        }#Seppli> <http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/name> 'Seppli'.
      }
    `;

    console.log(insertQuery);

    await engine.queryVoid(insertQuery, {
      sources: [getDefaultSession().info.webId!],
      "@comunica/actor-http-inrupt-solid-client-authn:session":
        getDefaultSession(),
    });

Full code available here. But it fails with this error: Unsupported patch content type: text/plain.

Environment:

software version
Comunica Engine 2.0.6
node v16.14.0

repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :heavy_plus_sign: Feature request ____ #### Description: Currently, Comunica only exposes CommonJS modules for Node.js. In the future, we should expose both ESM and CJS modules, as this will make it easier to use Comunica in other environments, like the browser. Some pointers: - https://2ality.com/2021/06/typescript-esm-nodejs.html - https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/modules.html - https://github.com/RubenVerborgh/AsyncIterator/blob/main/package.json Related to #857. ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | *Variable budget* | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Issue type:

  • ‚ûï Feature request

Description:

Currently, Comunica only exposes CommonJS modules for Node.js.
In the future, we should expose both ESM and CJS modules, as this will make it easier to use Comunica in other environments, like the browser.

Some pointers:

  • https://2ality.com/2021/06/typescript-esm-nodejs.html
  • https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/modules.html

nodes.title: ORDER BY is not implemented completely

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.bodyHTML:
This issue has been modified by @rubensworks to describe the intended solution

Apparently, we only support ordering by literal values, and a total ordering as mentioned in the SPARQL spec has not been implemented yet.

The goal of this issue is to properly implement total ordering in sparqlee (with the necessary unit tests), and optionally some integration tests here in Comunica.

Issue type:

  • üêõ Bug

Description:

Running queries with ORDER BY on @comunica/actor-init-sparql-file, IRIs are not sorted.

Relevant paragraph in the SPARQL 1.1 Spec (https://www.w3.org/TR/sparql11-query/#modOrderBy):

The "<" operator (see the Operator Mapping and 17.3.1 Operator Extensibility) defines the relative order of pairs of numerics, simple literals, xsd:strings, xsd:booleans and xsd:dateTimes. Pairs of IRIs are ordered by comparing them as simple literals.

Example (using VALUES for self-containment, but I've found the same issue with actual input sources):

import { newEngine } from '@comunica/actor-init-sparql-file'

const query = `
  PREFIX ex: <http://example.org/>
  SELECT ?x
  WHERE {
    VALUES ?x {ex:b ex:a ex:c}
  } ORDER BY ?x`;

const engine = newEngine();
const resPromise = engine.query(query);

// show the results
resPromise
  .then((result) => result.bindings())
  .then((ba) => ba.map((b) => Object.fromEntries(b.entries())))
  .then(console.log);

// expected output:
//
// [
//   {
//     '?x': NamedNode { termType: 'NamedNode', value: 'http://example.org/a' }
//   },
//   {
//     '?x': NamedNode { termType: 'NamedNode', value: 'http://example.org/b' }
//   },
//   {
//     '?x': NamedNode { termType: 'NamedNode', value: 'http://example.org/c' }
//   }
// ]

// actual output:
//
// [
//   {
//     '?x': NamedNode { termType: 'NamedNode', value: 'http://example.org/b' }
//   },
//   {
//     '?x': NamedNode { termType: 'NamedNode', value: 'http://example.org/a' }
//   },
//   {
//     '?x': NamedNode { termType: 'NamedNode', value: 'http://example.org/c' }
//   }
// ]

Environment:

Result of running from my package node node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/bin/query.js -v

software version
Comunica Init Actor 1.22.3
node v14.18.1
npm 6.14.15
yarn 1.22.17
Operating System linux (Linux 5.4.0-48-generic)

Crash log:

Not applicable.

Bounty

A bounty has been placed on this issue by:
‚Ç¨544

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: Remove dependency on Node.js APIs

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :heavy_plus_sign: Feature request ____ #### Description: Currently, when trying to bundle Comunica via tools such as Webpack (>= 5.x) requires users to manually configure polyfills for Node.js built-ins. We should make this process easier by not directly depending on Node.js built-ins, and instead use libraries such as `readable-stream`. This will also require some changes to several dependencies, such as RDF parsers. We should ensure that no such Node.js built-in dependencies are added in the future, either via a linter rule if that exists, or via a webpack process during CI. We should make sure that we don't see any performance degradations because of this. **The end-result of this issue should be that we can run webpack 5 on @comunica/query-sparql without having to configure any polyfills.** Also add `"sideEffects": false` to package.json where applicable. Related to : * https://github.com/rubensworks/jsonld-streaming-parser.js/issues/78 * https://github.com/rubensworks/rdfa-streaming-parser.js * https://github.com/rubensworks/microdata-rdf-streaming-parser.js * https://github.com/rdfjs/rdfxml-streaming-parser.js * https://github.com/rubensworks/rdf-dereference.js/issues/32 * *And possibly several others* ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | *Variable budget* | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Issue type:

  • ‚ûï Feature request

Description:

Currently, when trying to bundle Comunica via tools such as Webpack (>= 5.x) requires users to manually configure polyfills for Node.js built-ins. We should make this process easier by not directly depending on Node.js built-ins, and instead use libraries such as readable-stream.

This will also require some changes to several dependencies, such as RDF parsers.

We should ensure that no such Node.js built-in dependencies are added in the future, either via a linter rule if that exists, or via a webpack process during CI.

We should make sure that we don't see any performance degradations because of this.

The end-result of this issue should be that we can run webpack 5 on @comunica/query-sparql without having to configure any polyfills.

Also add "sideEffects": false to package.json where applicable.

Related to :

  • rubensworks/jsonld-streaming-parser.js#78
  • https://github.com/rubensworks/rdfa-streaming-parser.js
  • https://github.com/rubensworks/microdata-rdf-streaming-parser.js
  • https://github.com/rdfjs/rdfxml-streaming-parser.js
  • rubensworks/rdf-dereference.js#32
  • And possibly several others

nodes.title: Send original SPARQL query string to endpoints

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: _This issue has been modified by @rubensworks to describe the intended solution_ The problem is that we always parse the incoming query, and serialize it again when we send it to a SPARQL endpoint. Since this parsing-serializing process sometimes results in slightly different queries, this may cause issues for certain use cases. To solve this, we need to keep track of the original query string, and use that one in the case of querying a SPARQL endpoint. In actor-init-sparql, we need to add the original query string into the context. In `actor-query-operation-sparql-endpoint`, we need to check this context entry, and use that one if it exists. The only difficulty here is that we have to make sure that this context entry does not propagate to places where it shouldn't. For example, if this actor is only used because of a `SERVICE` keyword, we need to make sure that the actor still uses the `SERVICE` operation instead of the full original query. We could do this by just making sure that the service operator unsets or overrides this entry. ----- Original issue: #### Issue type: - :question: Question ____ #### Question: I want to query SPARQL endpoint `https://data.muziekschatten.nl/sparql`, backed by Virtuoso, using the query underneath: ```sparql SELECT * WHERE { ?uri ; ?label. FILTER((?label, "emile")) BIND("no name" AS ?name) } LIMIT 100 ``` It's a silly query - but the crucial parts are the `FILTER` and the `BIND`. If I execute this using Comunica... `npx comunica-sparql sparql@https://data.muziekschatten.nl/sparql -f query.rq` ...where file `query.rq` contains the query above...then the result is: `[Invalid SPARQL endpoint (https://data.muziekschatten.nl/sparql) response: undefined` My guess is that Comunica is rewriting the query, e.g. to: ```sparql SELECT * WHERE { ?uri ; ?label. BIND("no name" AS ?name) FILTER((?label, "emile")) } LIMIT 100 ``` `FILTER` is placed after `BIND`. If I execute this query via the endpoint's query editor on `https://data.muziekschatten.nl/sparql`, then Virtuoso yields the error: `Virtuoso 37000 Error SP031: SPARQL compiler: The group does not contain triple pattern with '$label' object before bif:contains() predicate`. Is it possible to influence the way that Comunica rewrites the query? ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://netwerkdigitaalerfgoed.nl/) | | ‚Ç¨544 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
This issue has been modified by @rubensworks to describe the intended solution

The problem is that we always parse the incoming query, and serialize it again when we send it to a SPARQL endpoint. Since this parsing-serializing process sometimes results in slightly different queries, this may cause issues for certain use cases. To solve this, we need to keep track of the original query string, and use that one in the case of querying a SPARQL endpoint.

In actor-init-sparql, we need to add the original query string into the context.
In actor-query-operation-sparql-endpoint, we need to check this context entry, and use that one if it exists.

The only difficulty here is that we have to make sure that this context entry does not propagate to places where it shouldn't. For example, if this actor is only used because of a SERVICE keyword, we need to make sure that the actor still uses the SERVICE operation instead of the full original query. We could do this by just making sure that the service operator unsets or overrides this entry.

Original issue:

Issue type:

  • ‚ùì Question

Question:

I want to query SPARQL endpoint https://data.muziekschatten.nl/sparql, backed by Virtuoso, using the query underneath:

SELECT * WHERE {
  ?uri <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type> <http://schema.org/Person>;
    <http://schema.org/name> ?label.
  FILTER(<bif:contains>(?label, "emile"))
  BIND("no name" AS ?name)
}
LIMIT 100

It's a silly query - but the crucial parts are the FILTER and the BIND. If I execute this using Comunica...

npx comunica-sparql sparql@https://data.muziekschatten.nl/sparql -f query.rq

...where file query.rq contains the query above...then the result is:

[Invalid SPARQL endpoint (https://data.muziekschatten.nl/sparql) response: undefined

My guess is that Comunica is rewriting the query, e.g. to:

SELECT * WHERE {
  ?uri <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type> <http://schema.org/Person>;
    <http://schema.org/name> ?label.
  BIND("no name" AS ?name)
  FILTER(<bif:contains>(?label, "emile"))
}
LIMIT 100

FILTER is placed after BIND. If I execute this query via the endpoint's query editor on https://data.muziekschatten.nl/sparql, then Virtuoso yields the error:

Virtuoso 37000 Error SP031: SPARQL compiler: The group does not contain triple pattern with '$label' object before bif:contains() predicate.

Is it possible to influence the way that Comunica rewrites the query?

Bounty

A bounty has been placed on this issue by:
‚Ç¨544

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: Implement OPT+ operator

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :heavy_plus_sign: Feature request ____ #### Description: The standard OPTIONAL operator is SPARQL is non-monotonic, which can lead to problem with streaming results. Concretely, intermediary results that do _not_ match with an OPTIONAL block will not be emitted until the whole relevant part of the dataset is handled. In practise, this means that some results will not become available to the user as soon as possible. The paper ["OPT+: A Monotonic Alternative to OPTIONAL in SPARQL" (by Sijin Cheng and Olaf Hartig)](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/333627321_OPT_A_Monotonic_Alternativeto_OPTIONAL_in_SPARQL) introduces the OPT+ operator, which makes OPTIONAL monotonic by changing its semantics (`A OPT+ B = (A AND B) UNION A`). The modified nested loop join algorithm from the paper (others are proposed) seems to achieve the best results. We can create a modified version (or provide a config option) of our OPTIONAL actor (`actor-query-operation-leftjoin-nestedloop`) that considers this modification. In essence, this modification means that a result can be emitted twice: once _without_ the optional binding, and once _with_ the optional binding. Since this modification is not strictly spec-compliant anymore, we should not enable it by default. But having it available can be useful for many use cases, especially when we have many sources (or when we are doing link traversal). ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨1088 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Issue type:

  • ‚ûï Feature request

Description:

The standard OPTIONAL operator is SPARQL is non-monotonic, which can lead to problem with streaming results. Concretely, intermediary results that do not match with an OPTIONAL block will not be emitted until the whole relevant part of the dataset is handled. In practise, this means that some results will not become available to the user as soon as possible.

The paper "OPT+: A Monotonic Alternative to OPTIONAL in SPARQL" (by Sijin Cheng and Olaf Hartig)
introduces the OPT+ operator, which makes OPTIONAL monotonic by changing its semantics (A OPT+ B = (A AND B) UNION A).

The modified nested loop join algorithm from the paper (others are proposed) seems to achieve the best results.

We can create a modified version (or provide a config option) of our OPTIONAL actor (actor-query-operation-leftjoin-nestedloop) that considers this modification.
In essence, this modification means that a result can be emitted twice: once without the optional binding, and once with the optional binding.

Since this modification is not strictly spec-compliant anymore, we should not enable it by default. But having it available can be useful for many use cases, especially when we have many sources (or when we are doing link traversal).

Bounty

‚Ç¨1088

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: Ensure backpressure is maintained in streams

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: #### Issue type: - :bug: Bug ____ #### Description: There seem to be a couple of places where we are not adhering to Node's backpressure conventions with regards to streams. Concretely, we seem to be creating new streams (such as `Readable`, `PassThrough` and `Transform`), and `push`-ing into them (via a `'data'` handler on another stream). Node handles backpressuring via the return value of `push`, which we are ignoring in this manner. https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Acomunica%2Fcomunica%20on(%27data&type=code A better solution would be to simply `pipe` instead of calling `push` on each data element. Related to https://github.com/rubensworks/rdf-parse.js/commit/269c757935c54b388e1bde076dc29c2afc2e8e7b ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨1088 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Issue type:

  • üêõ Bug

Description:

There seem to be a couple of places where we are not adhering to Node's backpressure conventions with regards to streams.

Concretely, we seem to be creating new streams (such as Readable, PassThrough and Transform), and push-ing into them (via a 'data' handler on another stream). Node handles backpressuring via the return value of push, which we are ignoring in this manner.

https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Acomunica%2Fcomunica%20on(%27data&type=code

A better solution would be to simply pipe instead of calling push on each data element.

Related to rubensworks/rdf-parse.js@269c757

Bounty

‚Ç¨1088

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: Throwing `Projection of ungrouped variable` error on valid query

repository.name: SPARQL.js
repository.description: A parser for the SPARQL query language in JavaScript

nodes.body: We're encountering issues with the most recent sparqljs releases, where the error checking is too strict. This query is valid, but throws an `Projection of ungrouped variable (?p)` error: ``` select ?p (count(*) as ?n) { [ ?p [] ]. } ``` This seems to be introduced by this PR: #108 ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://triply.cc/) | | ‚Ç¨272 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
We're encountering issues with the most recent sparqljs releases, where the error checking is too strict.
This query is valid, but throws an Projection of ungrouped variable (?p) error:

select ?p (count(*) as ?n) {
  [ ?p [] ].
}

This seems to be introduced by this PR: #108

nodes.title: URL encoded strings are decoded in IRIs

repository.name: rdfxml-streaming-parser.js
repository.description: Streaming RDF/XML parser

nodes.body: Hi, I have a rdf-xml file where an IRI contains the character sequence ` `, which is a URL encoding for newlines (`\n`). In the output of rdfxml-streaming-parser, this string is decoded, so that my IRI now instead contains `\n`. The same can be seen for other strings such as `>` and `<`. This is different from what N3 does for turtle-family parsing. I'm not certain which approach would be correct. ```javascript const fs = require('fs'); const RdfXmlParser = require("rdfxml-streaming-parser").RdfXmlParser; const N3 = require('n3'); fs.createReadStream('test.rdf') .pipe(new RdfXmlParser()) .on('data', console.log) fs.createReadStream('test.ttl') .pipe(new N3.StreamParser()) .on('data', console.log) ``` input files: ```rdf ``` ```turtle . ``` output: ``` Quad { subject: NamedNode { value: 'a:\n' }, predicate: NamedNode { value: 'b:b' }, object: NamedNode { value: 'c:c' }, graph: DefaultGraph { value: '' } } Quad { subject: NamedNode { id: 'a: ' }, predicate: NamedNode { id: 'b:b' }, object: NamedNode { id: 'c:c' }, graph: DefaultGraph { id: '' } } ``` ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://triply.cc/) | | ‚Ç¨544 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: Parsing issue with SPARQL query on inverse paths in anonymous node

repository.name: SPARQL.js
repository.description: A parser for the SPARQL query language in JavaScript

nodes.body: _Originally reported in by https://github.com/comunica/comunica/issues/677 @jaw111._ There is an odd combination of syntax that is flagged as an error. ```sparql SELECT * WHERE { ?movie a dbpedia-owl:Film ; dbpedia-owl:starring [ rdfs:label "Brad Pitt"@en ; ^dbpedia-owl:starring ?otherMovie ] . } ``` Gives the error: ``` # Parse error on line 21: ...ad Pitt"@en ; ^dbpedia-owl:starrin ----------------------^ Expecting 'IRIREF', 'PNAME_NS', 'VAR', '}', 'GRAPH', ';', 'a', ']', 'PNAME_LN', '.', got '^' ``` Whilst removing the triple pattern for `a` works just fine: ```sparql SELECT * WHERE { ?movie dbpedia-owl:starring [ rdfs:label "Brad Pitt"@en ; ^dbpedia-owl:starring ?otherMovie ] . } ``` ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://triply.cc/) | | ‚Ç¨272 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
Originally reported in by comunica/comunica#677 @jaw111.

There is an odd combination of syntax that is flagged as an error.

SELECT *
WHERE {
  ?movie a dbpedia-owl:Film ;
    dbpedia-owl:starring [
      rdfs:label "Brad Pitt"@en ;
      ^dbpedia-owl:starring ?otherMovie
    ] .
}

Gives the error:

# Parse error on line 21:
...ad Pitt"@en ;      ^dbpedia-owl:starrin
----------------------^
Expecting 'IRIREF', 'PNAME_NS', 'VAR', '}', 'GRAPH', ';', 'a', ']', 'PNAME_LN', '.', got '^'

Whilst removing the triple pattern for a works just fine:

SELECT *
WHERE {
  ?movie
    dbpedia-owl:starring [
      rdfs:label "Brad Pitt"@en ;
      ^dbpedia-owl:starring ?otherMovie
    ] .
}

‚Ç¨272

nodes.title: Clearer error reporting for incorrect input

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: _This issue has been modified by @rubensworks to describe the intended solution_ **Problem:** The problem is that some (most?) errors that can be produced by Comunica are quite cryptic. This is a consequence of inter-actor communication happening via mediators, which can produce errors such as: ``` Error: https://.../rdf-dereference.json#mediatorRdfParse mediated over all rejecting actors: Error: Unrecognized media type: text/html Error: Unrecognized media type: text/html Error: Unrecognized media type: text/html at MediatorRace.js:55 ``` So the common format is that mediators show an error message that accumulates error messages from failing actors. **Possible solution:** One possible solution could be to reformat these types of error messages to something roughly like: ``` Error: RDF parsing failed: none of the configured parsers were able to handle the content type 'text/html'. Error messages of failing actors: ActorNameX: Unrecognized media type: text/html ActorNameY: Unrecognized media type: text/html ActorNameZ: Unrecognized media type: text/html ``` (certainly open to other suggestions) **Implementation suggestions:** We could have mediators accept an error message format (with placeholders for things such as `contentType` in parsing actions). Each mediator would also require some polishing (and alignment) in how it produces error messages. Something like the following should be possible: `mediator.mediate(action, (failReasons) => 'This is an error message')` ----- Original issue: #### Issue type: - :heavy_plus_sign: Feature request #### Description: When invoking `comunica-sparql` with (for instance) an error in the query, I get: ``` Error: Unknown prefix: schema at Object.anonymous (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/sparqljs/lib/SparqlParser.js:498:29) at Parser.parse (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/sparqljs/lib/SparqlParser.js:642:36) at Parser.parser.parse (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/sparqljs/sparql.js:22:37) at Object.translate (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/sparqlalgebrajs/lib/sparqlAlgebra.js:30:25) at ActorSparqlParseAlgebra.run (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/@comunica/actor-sparql-parse-algebra/lib/ActorSparqlParseAlgebra.js:16:47) at MediatorRace.mediate (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/@comunica/core/lib/Mediator.js:80:22) at at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:188:7) at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:686:11) at startup (bootstrap_node.js:187:16) ``` Would be helpful to a) hide the stacktrace (only show it when a certain flag is set) and b) for this particular case, make the error message (a bit) more descriptive. ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨1632 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
This issue has been modified by @rubensworks to describe the intended solution

Problem:

The problem is that some (most?) errors that can be produced by Comunica are quite cryptic.
This is a consequence of inter-actor communication happening via mediators, which can produce errors such as:

Error: https://.../rdf-dereference.json#mediatorRdfParse mediated over all rejecting actors:
Error: Unrecognized media type: text/html
Error: Unrecognized media type: text/html
Error: Unrecognized media type: text/html
    at MediatorRace.js:55

So the common format is that mediators show an error message that accumulates error messages from failing actors.

Possible solution:

One possible solution could be to reformat these types of error messages to something roughly like:

Error: RDF parsing failed: none of the configured parsers were able to handle the content type 'text/html'.
  Error messages of failing actors:
    ActorNameX: Unrecognized media type: text/html
    ActorNameY: Unrecognized media type: text/html
    ActorNameZ: Unrecognized media type: text/html

(certainly open to other suggestions)

Implementation suggestions:

We could have mediators accept an error message format (with placeholders for things such as contentType in parsing actions).

Each mediator would also require some polishing (and alignment) in how it produces error messages.

Something like the following should be possible: mediator.mediate(action, (failReasons) => 'This is an error message')

Original issue:

Issue type:

  • ‚ûï Feature request

Description:

When invoking comunica-sparql with (for instance) an error in the query, I get:

Error: Unknown prefix: schema
    at Object.anonymous (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/sparqljs/lib/SparqlParser.js:498:29)
    at Parser.parse (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/sparqljs/lib/SparqlParser.js:642:36)
    at Parser.parser.parse (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/sparqljs/sparql.js:22:37)
    at Object.translate (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/sparqlalgebrajs/lib/sparqlAlgebra.js:30:25)
    at ActorSparqlParseAlgebra.run (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/@comunica/actor-sparql-parse-algebra/lib/ActorSparqlParseAlgebra.js:16:47)
    at MediatorRace.mediate (/Users/ruben/.nvm/versions/node/v8.9.4/lib/node_modules/@comunica/actor-init-sparql/node_modules/@comunica/core/lib/Mediator.js:80:22)
    at <anonymous>
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:188:7)
    at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:686:11)
    at startup (bootstrap_node.js:187:16)

Would be helpful to a) hide the stacktrace (only show it when a certain flag is set) and b) for this particular case, make the error message (a bit) more descriptive.

Bounty

A bounty has been placed on this issue by:
‚Ç¨1632

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.

nodes.title: Allow HTTP timeout configuration

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: We should allow users to pass an HTTP timeout value via the context (`httpTimeout`). This could be implemented using our own `setTimeout` and the fetch `AbortController`: https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch/issues/95 We should keep in mind here that we should clear our own timeout once the request completes (response object is available). Additionally, we need an extra context option (boolean: `httpTimeoutOnBody`) to make it so that the timeout not only applies to the time until response starts coming in, but also to the time until the response body is fully available. The latter could take longer, or potentially be infinite for e.g. continuous data streams. This should also take into account that response bodies can be cancelled from within Comunica. ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://netwerkdigitaalerfgoed.nl/) | | ‚Ç¨1088 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
We should allow users to pass an HTTP timeout value via the context (httpTimeout).

This could be implemented using our own setTimeout and the fetch AbortController: node-fetch/node-fetch#95

We should keep in mind here that we should clear our own timeout once the request completes (response object is available).

Additionally, we need an extra context option (boolean: httpTimeoutOnBody) to make it so that the timeout not only applies to the time until response starts coming in, but also to the time until the response body is fully available. The latter could take longer, or potentially be infinite for e.g. continuous data streams. This should also take into account that response bodies can be cancelled from within Comunica.

Bounty

A bounty has been placed on this issue by:
‚Ç¨1088

nodes.title: Add identity-based DISTINCT actor

repository.name: comunica
repository.description: üì¨ A knowledge graph querying framework for JavaScript

nodes.body: The current DISTINCT implementation works based on hashes. ~~While the chance of clashes is quite small~~, we should add an identity-based implementation as well. **EDIT:** The chance of clashes became higher (#1510), and this is causing issues now. This could work by for example just stringifying each object (e.g. using rdf-string), instead of hashing it. We should add this in a new `actor-query-operation-distinct-identity` actor, as alternative to `actor-query-operation-distinct-hash`. ----- ## Bounty A [bounty](https://comunica.dev/association/bounties/) has been placed on this issue by: | | |-| | [](https://comunica.dev/association/) | | ‚Ç¨544 | [Click here to learn more](https://comunica.dev/association/bounty_process/) if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
nodes.bodyHTML:
The current DISTINCT implementation works based on hashes. While the chance of clashes is quite small, we should add an identity-based implementation as well.
EDIT: The chance of clashes became higher (#1510), and this is causing issues now.

This could work by for example just stringifying each object (e.g. using rdf-string), instead of hashing it.

We should add this in a new actor-query-operation-distinct-identity actor, as alternative to actor-query-operation-distinct-hash.

Bounty

A bounty has been placed on this issue by:
‚Ç¨544

Click here to learn more if you're interested in claiming this bounty by resolving this issue.
